ParentCompanyName: E.I. DuPont de Nemours & Company, Inc.
OperatorName: E.I. DuPont de Nemours & Company, I

_prev_prog_3.MS_OtherType: There is a containment sump adjacent to the tank and the site Emergency Response Team maintains foam for mitigation of a release.  The ERT is staffed 24 hrs/day, 365 days/year.
_prev_prog_3.MD_OtherType: Employees are present at all times while a tanker is being unoaded.  The area is staffed 24 hrs/day, 365 days/year and leak patrols are routinely made.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENT RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES
At the DuPont Fayetteville Works, we are committed to operating and maintaining our processes in a safe and responsible manner.  We use a combination of accident release prevention programs and emergency response planning programs to help insure the safety of our employees, the public and the environment.  We adhere to the DuPont Corporate philosophy of the commitment is zero.  This means that we constantly strive for zero process safety incidents, zero environmental incidents and zero injuries.  Our site safety, operating and emergency response procedures are available to all site employees thorough hard copies and/or electronic copies on computers throughout the plant.

FACILITY DESCRIPTION
The DuPont Fayetteville Works consists of approximately 2200 acres located on the Bladen - Cumberland county line, adjacent to N.C. highway 87, approximately 15 miles southeast of Fayetteville, N.C.  Approximately 400 acres are currently used for manufacturing, with the remainder set-aside for future manufacturing needs.

The Nafion process at Fayetteville is a Prevention Program 3 processes due to regulated toxic chemicals with off-site impact potential.    The Nafion process produces chemical intermediates using Sulfur Trioxide.

The TFE and Polyvinyl Fluoride processes are Prevention Program 1 processes since the regulated chemicals are flammables with no off-site impact.  TFE is used to produces a membrane used in fuel cells and the Chloralkali industry.  In the production of those products, the regulated substance Tetrafluoroethylene is used.  
Polyvinyl Fluoride is the polymer used in TEDLAR.  It is a film product with multiple applications.  The polymer is produced at Fayetteville Works and shipped to other DuPont sites for final processing.  The regulated substance Vinyl Fluoride is used in the Polyvinyl Fluoride manufacturing process.

ACCIDENT RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM
The DuPont Fayetteville Wor

ks is in compliance with the requirements of 29 CFR 1910.119 and 40 CFR Part 68.  Our Process Safety Management system includes a documented process technology system detailing the hazards of the materials, equipment design basis and the process design basis.  Periodic Process Hazards Analyses are conducted to review the entire process to insure safe operation and compliance with design guidelines.  Materials of construction are strictly controlled to insure the mechanical integrity of the systems.  Extensive operating and safety instrumentation include alarms, interlocks and gas detectors that allow the operators to continuously monitor and control the process conditions.  Process safety critical equipment and instruments are identified and routinely tested or inspected to insure proper operation and mechanical integrity.  A work order and permit system is used to control maintenance work.  Maintenance and operations personnel are trained and qualified via a rigorous training program.  Operating and maintenance procedures are documented and available to personnel either via hard copy or electronic copies on computers located throughout the operating areas. 

 FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
There have been no on site injuries and no off site injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage or environmental damage due the accidental release of RMP regulated substances from the DuPont Fayetteville Works in the past 5 years. 

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
The site has an emergency response team staffed 24 hrs/day, 365 days/year that is trained to respond to fire, medical or hazmat emergencies.  Our emergency response program provides planning and training to effectively protect our employees, the public and the environment during emergency situations.  The emergency response procedures are in place and updated periodically.  All employees are trained for their role in an emergency situation.  The plant conducts emergency response drills, with critiques held

after the drills and actual events.  The plant is actively involved with the Bladen County LEPC.

IMPROVING SAFETY
We constantly strive to evaluate and improve the safety of our processes.  Every person on the site has a responsibility to improve the safety of our operations.  As part of our Process Hazards Analysis process, teams consisting of operators, mechanics, technical engineers and management thoroughly examine and evaluate our manufacturing operations on a periodic frequency to identify risk reduction opportunities.  Audits, both first party and second party, are conducted using site based personnel and non-site personnel to evaluate compliance with safety, environmental, occupational health and process safety management requirements and regulations.  Findings are documented and tracked to closure.
